subject: Economics
title: Fractional Reserve Banking: Money from Thin Air
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Fractional Reserve Banking: Money from Thin Air.

hook.text: When you deposit $1,000, the bank keeps $100 and lends $900 to someone else. Both of you think you have money.

buildup.text: That $900 loan gets deposited elsewhere. That bank lends $810. The cycle repeats, creating money from one deposit.

discovery.text: From your $1,000, the banking system can create up to $10,000 in total deposits. This is the money multiplier.

twist.text: This works perfectly â€” until everyone wants their money back at once. Then there isn't enough. That's a bank run.

climax.text: Most money in circulation was never printed. Banks created it by lending the same dollar over and over.

punchline.text: 90% of money exists only because banks promised it to two people.

quiz.question: What is fractional reserve banking?
options: Banks keep all deposits in vaults
Banks keep a fraction of deposits and lend the rest, creating new money
